title: $8 Million Minimalist’s Dream Home Hits the Market in SoHo
text:
A newly renovated loft space in downtown Manhattan takes the Marie Kondo gospel of decluttering to a whole new level.



The three-bedroom condo sits in the middle of a century-old brick building in SoHo that once served as a hotspot for New York City’s “loft jazz” scene in the 1970s, a continuation of the improvisational free jazz movement.



But there was no room to ad-lib when it came to the exacting minimalist makeover of this fifth-floor apartment, which will hit the market for $8 million.



More: Why Biggest is Rarely Best in Real Estate

The unit features the clean lines of 12-inch oak floors, crisp white walls and slabs of travertine marble and black granite, according to the listing with Leonard Steinberg and his team at Compass.



“Most designers, architects and owners measure things in inches, but this owner measures in millimeters,” Mr. Steinberg said. “Any contractor will tell you installing minimalism is the most difficult of all because there is no room for mistakes.”



The battle against clutter in this apartment goes beyond the typical clean-lined contemporary architecture popular in the city’s new developments.



The open kitchen, HQ for mess in most homes, has numerous safeguards against it, including a black granite countertop that slides open and close to hide the six-burner stovetop, and a fridge that blends seamlessly into rows of milled custom cabinetry.



Sliding walls into the master suite and a discrete office hidden behind flush paneled doors also keep things looking streamlined, according to the listing description.



The mastermind behind this minimalist’s dream home is an investment banker who purchased the unit as an empty shell three years ago for $4 million, according to property records. He could not immediately be reached for comment.



Images of the unit from before his ownership show a true blank white box with shabby wood floors, a kitchen space and bathroom. The unit didn’t even have a certificate of occupancy at the time, Mr. Steinberg said.

The seller’s aesthetic choices and attention to detail, the agent said, reflect a passion for fine yachts, which tend to employ stripped-down clean design and light neutral colors to help maximize their limited space.



The home also benefits from “fortress”-like two-foot-thick walls, which block out the noise from its location on busy Broadway, and windows on three sides, Mr. Steinberg said. The apartment also comes with access to a shared rooftop terrace.



Thirty-plus year ago, the 11-story building was home to Environ, a performance space that hosted some of the city’s leading jazz musicians and performers of the mid-’70s, including jazz great Dave Brubeck, avant-garde composer Laurie Spiegel and dancer Martha Graham, according to the listing agency.
